problems.title: Replace Elements with Factorial
problems.description:
Replace each element in the array with its factorial value. Print the modified array with space-separated values. Note: For negative numbers, consider absolute value. For 0, factorial is 1. For large numbers, use appropriate data types.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the modified array with factorial values, space-separated.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5
1 2 3 4 5

Sample Output
1 2 6 24 120

Explanation:
Factorials: 1! = 1, 2! = 2, 3! = 6, 4! = 24, 5! = 120
hintsList: Use a loop to compute factorials for each element.

problems.title: Next Greater Element
problems.description:
Write a program to print next greater elements in a given unsorted array. For each element, find the next greater element to its right. Elements for which no greater element exists, consider the next greater element as -1.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the next greater elements array with space-separated values.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
6
5 3 10 9 6 13

Sample Output
10 10 13 13 13 -1

Explanation:
Next bigger element of 5 is 10 (first greater to the right)
Next bigger element of 3 is 10 (first greater to the right)
Next bigger element of 10 is 13 (first greater to the right)
Next bigger element of 9 is 13 (first greater to the right)
Next bigger element of 6 is 13 (first greater to the right)
Next bigger element of 13 is -1 (no greater element to the right)
hintsList: Use nested loops: for each element, scan to the right to find first greater element.
Optimize using a stack to achieve O(n) time complexity.

problems.title: Subarray with Given Sum
problems.description:
Write a program to find all subarrays with given sum from the given array. Print the start and end indices of each subarray.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.
Third line contains target, the target sum.

Output Format:
Print each subarray range in format "[start..end] -- { elements }", each on a new line. Elements should be space-separated.
hintsList: Use nested loops to check all possible subarrays starting from each index.
Use prefix sum technique to optimize the solution.

problems.title: Move Zeroes to End
problems.description:
Write a program to move all zeroes to the end of a given array while maintaining the relative order of non-zero elements.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the modified array with all zeroes moved to the end, space-separated.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
10
2 5 7 0 4 0 7 -5 8 0

Sample Output
2 5 7 4 7 -5 8 0 0 0

Explanation:
All zeroes are moved to the end while non-zero elements maintain their relative order.
hintsList: Use two pointers: one to track position for non-zero elements, another to traverse the array.

problems.title: Maximum Difference
problems.description:
Write a program to find out the maximum difference between any two elements such that the larger element appears after the smaller number.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print the two elements that provide maximum difference, followed by the maximum difference value. Format: "The elements which provide maximum difference is: X, Y\nThe Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: Z"
problems.examples:
Sample Input
6
7 9 5 6 13 2

Sample Output
The elements which provide maximum difference is: 5, 13
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 8

Explanation:
The maximum difference is 13 - 5 = 8, where 5 appears before 13.

testCases.expectedOutput:
The elements which provide maximum difference is: 5, 13
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 8

The elements which provide maximum difference is: 2, 10
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 8

The elements which provide maximum difference is: 7, 9
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 2

The elements which provide maximum difference is: 10, 10
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 0

The elements which provide maximum difference is: 1, 5
The Maximum difference between two elements in the array is: 4

hintsList: Track the minimum element seen so far and calculate difference with current element.
Maintain minimum value and maximum difference while traversing the array.

problems.title: Array Number Operations
problems.description:
Write a program to take input array  of numbers and perform different operations on each number:

Case 1: Sort digits in ascending order
Case 2: Sort digits in descending order
Case 3: Calculate sum of digits
Case 4: Rearrange digits - even digits first, then odd digits (maintaining relative order)
Case 5: Extract only prime digits (2, 3, 5, 7)

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.
Third line contains case number (1-5).

Output Format:
Print the result array with space-separated values.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
6
5732 8659 2534 9625 7354 1325
1

Sample Output
2357 5689 2345 2569 3457 1235

Explanation:
Case 1: Sort digits of each number in ascending order.
5732 -> 2357, 8659 -> 5689, etc.
hintsList: Convert each number to digits, perform operation, then reconstruct the number.
Case 4: Separate even and odd digits, then combine them.
Case 5: Filter digits to only include primes (2, 3, 5, 7).

problems.title: Find Ceiling in Sorted Array
problems.description:
Given a sorted array in ascending order and a value x, find the ceiling of x. The ceiling of x is the smallest element in the array greater than or equal to x. If no such element exists, return -1.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers (sorted in ascending order).
Third line contains x, the target value.

Output Format:
Print "The ceiling of x is: Y" where Y is the ceiling value, or "The ceiling of x is: -1" if not found.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
8
1 3 4 7 8 9 9 10
5

Sample Output
The ceiling of 5 is: 7

Explanation:
The ceiling of 5 is the smallest element >= 5, which is 7.
problems.constraints:
1 <= n <= 1000
-10^9 <= arr[i] <= 10^9
-10^9 <= x <= 10^9
Array is sorted in ascending order

testCases.expectedOutput: The ceiling of 5 is: 7
The ceiling of 4 is: 5
The ceiling of 6 is: -1
The ceiling of 2 is: 2
The ceiling of 0 is: 1

hintsList: Use binary search to find the ceiling efficiently.
Ceiling is the smallest element >= x. If found, return it; otherwise return -1.

problems.title: Find Floor and Ceil for Numbers
problems.description:
Given a sorted array, find the floor and ceiling for numbers from 0 to 10. The floor of x is the greatest element smaller than or equal to x, and the ceiling is the smallest element greater than or equal to x.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers (sorted in ascending order).

Output Format:
For each number from 0 to 10, print "Number: X ceiling is: Y floor is: Z" on a separate line. Use -1 if floor/ceiling doesn't exist.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
6
1 3 5 7 8 9

Sample Output
Number: 0 ceiling is: 1 floor is: -1
Number: 1 ceiling is: 1 floor is: 1
Number: 2 ceiling is: 3 floor is: 1
Number: 3 ceiling is: 3 floor is: 3
Number: 4 ceiling is: 5 floor is: 3
Number: 5 ceiling is: 5 floor is: 5
Number: 6 ceiling is: 7 floor is: 5
Number: 7 ceiling is: 7 floor is: 7
Number: 8 ceiling is: 8 floor is: 8
Number: 9 ceiling is: 9 floor is: 9
Number: 10 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 9
problems.constraints:
1 <= n <= 1000
-10^9 <= arr[i] <= 10^9
Array is sorted in ascending order

testCases.expectedOutput:
Number: 0 ceiling is: 1 floor is: -1
Number: 1 ceiling is: 1 floor is: 1
Number: 2 ceiling is: 3 floor is: 1

Number: 10 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 9

Number: 0 ceiling is: 2 floor is: -1

Number: 2 ceiling is: 2 floor is: 2

Number: 4 ceiling is: 5 floor is: 2

Number: 6 ceiling is: 8 floor is: 5
Number: 7 ceiling is: 8 floor is: 5
Number: 8 ceiling is: 8 floor is: 8
Number: 9 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 8
Number: 10 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 8

Number: 0 ceiling is: 0 floor is: 0
Number: 1 ceiling is: 1 floor is: 1
Number: 2 ceiling is: 2 floor is: 2
Number: 3 ceiling is: 3 floor is: 3

Number: 6 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 3

Number: 8 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 3

Number: 10 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 3

Number: 0 ceiling is: 5 floor is: -1
Number: 1 ceiling is: 5 floor is: -1

Number: 10 ceiling is: -1 floor is: 5

hintsList: For each number from 0 to 10, find its floor and ceiling in the sorted array.
Use binary search or linear search to find floor and ceiling for each number.

problems.title: Two Elements Sum Closest to Zero
problems.description:
Find two elements in an array whose sum is closest to zero (minimum absolute sum).

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print "The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:" followed by the pair in format "[a, b]" on the next line.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
10
38 44 63 -51 -35 19 84 -69 4 -46

Sample Output
The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[44, -46]

Explanation:
The sum of 44 and -46 is -2, which has the minimum absolute value.

testCases.expectedOutput:
The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[44, -46]

The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[-80, 85]

The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[-5, 5]

The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[1, 2]

The Pair of elements whose sum is minimum are:
[-10, 10]

hintsList: Sort the array and use two pointers approach.
Track the minimum absolute sum and return the pair with minimum absolute sum.

problems.title: Maximum Circular Subarray Sum
problems.description:
Find the maximum sum of a circular subarray. A circular subarray means the array can wrap around, i.e., the last element connects to the first element.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print "The maximum circular sum in the above array is: X" where X is the maximum circular subarray sum.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
9
10 8 -20 5 -3 -5 10 -13 11

Sample Output
The maximum circular sum in the above array is: 29

Explanation:
The maximum circular sum can be achieved by taking elements from index 7 to index 1 (wrapping around): 11 + 10 + 8 = 29.

testCases.expectedOutput: The maximum circular sum in the above array is: 29
The maximum circular sum in the above array is: 19
The maximum circular sum in the above array is: 17
The maximum circular sum in the above array is: -1
The maximum circular sum in the above array is: 7

hintsList: Use Kadane's algorithm for maximum subarray sum in normal array.
For circular: max of (normal max subarray sum, total sum - minimum subarray sum).

problems.title: Count Inversions in Array
problems.description:
Count the number of inversions in an array. An inversion is a pair (i, j) such that i < j and arr[i] > arr[j].

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print all inversions in format "(arr[i], arr[j])" separated by spaces, then on the next line print "The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: X".
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5
1 9 6 4 5

Sample Output
The inversions are: (9, 6) (9, 4) (9, 5) (6, 4) (6, 5)
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 5

Explanation:
Inversions: (9,6), (9,4), (9,5), (6,4), (6,5) - total 5 inversions.

testCases.expectedOutput:
The inversions are: (9, 6) (9, 4) (9, 5) (6, 4) (6, 5)
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 5

The inversions are: (2, 1) (4, 1) (4, 3)
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 3

The inversions are: (3, 2) (3, 1) (2, 1)
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 3

The inversions are:
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 0

The inversions are: (3, 2)
The number of inversion can be formed from the array is: 1

hintsList: Use nested loops to check all pairs (i, j) where i < j and arr[i] > arr[j].
For efficiency, use merge sort approach to count inversions in O(n log n) time.

problems.title: Count Distinct Pairs for Specific Difference
problems.description:
Count all distinct pairs in an array with a specific difference. A pair (a, b) is distinct if a != b and |a - b| = diff.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.
Third line contains diff, the target difference.

Output Format:
Print all distinct pairs in format "[a, b]" separated by spaces, then on the next line print "Number of distinct pairs for difference diff are: X".
problems.examples:
Sample Input
8
5 2 3 7 6 4 9 8
5

Sample Output
The distinct pairs for difference 5 are: [7, 2] [8, 3] [9, 4]
Number of distinct pairs for difference 5 are: 3

Explanation:
Pairs with difference 5: (7,2), (8,3), (9,4).

testCases.expectedOutput:
The distinct pairs for difference 5 are: [7, 2] [8, 3] [9, 4]
Number of distinct pairs for difference 5 are: 3

The distinct pairs for difference 2 are: [3, 1] [5, 3] [4, 2]
Number of distinct pairs for difference 2 are: 3

The distinct pairs for difference 1 are: [2, 1] [3, 2] [4, 3]
Number of distinct pairs for difference 1 are: 3

The distinct pairs for difference 15 are:
Number of distinct pairs for difference 15 are: 0

The distinct pairs for difference 5 are: [10, 5] [15, 10] [20, 15] [25, 20]
Number of distinct pairs for difference 5 are: 4

hintsList: Use a hash set or sort the array and use two pointers.
For each element, check if (element + diff) or (element - diff) exists in the array.

problems.title: Maximum Repeating Number
problems.description:
Find the maximum repeating number in an array. The array range is [0..n-1] and elements are in range [0..k-1] where k <= n.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.
Third line contains k, the upper bound of element values.

Output Format:
Print "The maximum repeating number is: X" where X is the most frequent element.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
11
2 3 3 5 3 4 1 7 7 7 7
8

Sample Output
The maximum repeating number is: 7

Explanation:
Number 7 appears 4 times, which is more than any other number.

testCases.expectedOutput: The maximum repeating number is: 7
The maximum repeating number is: 1
The maximum repeating number is: 1
The maximum repeating number is: 0
The maximum repeating number is: 0

hintsList: Use a frequency array of size k to count occurrences of each number.

problems.title: All Combinations of R Elements
problems.description:
Print all possible combinations of r elements from a given array. Combinations should be printed in lexicographical order.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.
Third line contains r, the number of elements in each combination.

Output Format:
Print "The combinations are:" followed by all combinations, each on a new line, with elements space-separated.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5
1 5 4 6 8
4

Sample Output
The combinations are:
1 5 4 6
1 5 4 8
1 5 6 8
1 4 6 8
5 4 6 8

Explanation:
All combinations of 4 elements from the array of 5 elements.

testCases.expectedOutput:
The combinations are:
1 5 4 6
1 5 4 8
1 5 6 8
1 4 6 8
5 4 6 8

The combinations are:
1 2
1 3
1 4
2 3
2 4
3 4

The combinations are:
1 2 3

The combinations are:
10
20
30
40

hintsList: Use backtracking or recursion to generate all combinations.
Sort the array first to ensure lexicographical order in output.

problems.title: Pair with Given Difference
problems.description:
Find a pair of elements in a sorted array with a given difference.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers (sorted in ascending order).
Third line contains diff, the target difference.

Output Format:
Print "The pair are: (a, b)" where |a - b| = diff. If no pair exists, print "No pair found".
problems.examples:
Sample Input
5
1 15 39 75 92
53

Sample Output
The pair are: (39, 92)

Explanation:
92 - 39 = 53, which is the given difference.
problems.constraints:
1 <= n <= 1000
-10^9 <= arr[i] <= 10^9
1 <= diff <= 10^9
Array is sorted in ascending order

testCases.expectedOutput: The pair are: (39, 92)
The pair are: (1, 3)
No pair found
The pair are: (2, 6)
The pair are: (10, 20)

hintsList: Use two pointers technique since array is sorted.
For each element, check if (element + diff) or (element - diff) exists using binary search.

problems.title: Rearrange Positive and Negative Alternatively
problems.description:
Rearrange positive and negative numbers alternatively in a given array. If positive numbers are more, they appear at the end. If negative numbers are more, they too appear at the end of the array.

Input Format:
First line contains n, the size of array.
Second line contains n space-separated integers.

Output Format:
Print "The rearranged array is:" followed by the rearranged array with space-separated values.
problems.examples:
Sample Input
11
-4 8 -5 -6 5 -9 7 1 -21 -11 19

Sample Output
The rearranged array is:
-4 8 -5 5 -6 7 -9 1 -21 19 -11

Explanation:
Positive and negative numbers are arranged alternatively. Remaining numbers (more negatives) appear at the end.

testCases.expectedOutput:
The rearranged array is:
-4 8 -5 5 -6 7 -9 1 -21 19 -11

The rearranged array is:
-1 1 -2 2 -3 3

The rearranged array is:
-1 1 -2 2 -3

The rearranged array is:
-1 1 -2 2 3

The rearranged array is:
-1 2 -3 4

hintsList: Separate positive and negative numbers into two arrays.
Fill positions alternatively starting with negative, then place remaining numbers at the end.
